q: The Crown Prosecution Service has also asked a senior QC to`` comprehensively'' re-examine material amassed as part of the original inquiry and any new evidence. In his resignation statement, Mr Andy Coulson said: Nothing is more important than the Government's task of getting this country back on its feet.`` Unfortunately continued coverage of events connected to my old job at the News of the World has made it difficult for me to give the 110% needed in this role.`` I stand by what I've said about those events but when the spokesman needs a spokesman it's time to move on. Mr Andy Coulson joined Mr David Cameron 's team before the General Election and then ran the PM's communications strategy. we must be, because the loss of Andy Coulson 's link to ordinariness is considered to disadvantage Cameron, not just electorally, but in the sense that he will be a less complete and sympathetic politician without it. No politician can govern well, we believe, who does not understand what it is to be ordinary. But what about when an actual example of ordinariness shows his head, tells us what he thinks, allows us a glimpse, inadvertent or otherwise, into his unexamined biases and assumptions? David Letterman did a comedy bit many, many years ago called`` cause and effect,'' or something like that. We recall one of David Letterman 's jokes went like this: Cause: Millions of prairie dogs die of a mysterious disease.`` Effect: McRibs for a limited time. Anyway, that came to mind when we first heard about the documentary Return of the Prairie Bandit, which airs Thursday, Feb. 10 as part of The Nature of Things with David Suzuki on CBC.
